Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: ... It's crazy -- sugar is up to 200 dollars a ton -- sugar !

Speaker: lawyer
Dialogue: What about oil ?

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Food, oil --look, let me show you something. This is the economy of the United States in two years --

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Do you understand ?

Speaker: accountant
Dialogue: What's to prevent it ?

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Maybe nothing. But I'll tell you, I didn't build a two-billion-dollar company in the last twenty years by doing nothing. We can protect our interests.  We are still the most powerful nation in the world. Militarily.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: You know bodyguard; he was a captain in Viet Nam. You talk to him, except he won't talk. This kind of man can kill you with his pinky. A nice quiet fella, though.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: An Ingram Machine pistol.

Speaker: captain
Dialogue: How about a drink ?

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: Sure, thanks.

Speaker: captain
Dialogue: Winning the war by yourself.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: Part.

Speaker: captain
Dialogue: Which part is that ?

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: My part.  Beer, with ice and water.

Speaker: captain
Dialogue: That's good gin.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: I'm sure it is, but I had hepatitis.

Speaker: captain
Dialogue: Delta ?

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: captain
Dialogue: North ?

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: Yeah. Way north.

Speaker: captain
Dialogue: What unit were you with ?

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: None.

Speaker: captain
Dialogue: Rangers, eh?

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: Sort of.

Speaker: captain
Dialogue: Were you Longe Range Recon --

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: No -- I worked too far north for LRRP.

Speaker: captain
Dialogue: That's quite an array of ribbons...

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: Let's talk about you.

Speaker: captain
Dialogue: I was an FO for the 25th.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: Tracks ?

Speaker: captain
Dialogue: Yeah.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: Fat. That's real fat.

Speaker: captain
Dialogue: Sometimes.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: At least you always have enough water. How many gallons does each one of those damn things carry ?

Speaker: captain
Dialogue: Thirty -- sometimes fifty.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: You know, I can remember once, getting back below the DMZ -- and the first Americans we ran into were a track squadron. I just couldn't believe how much water they had. We'd been chewing bamboo shoots for almost a week, and before that, for two weeks, we'd been drinking anything -- rain water, river shit, stuff right out of the paddies. And there were these guys standing by their trucks spilling water all over. I could've killed them.  I swear to God I would have, too, if ...

Speaker: captain
Dialogue: I didn't know we had units up there in North Vietnam.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: We do.

Speaker: captain
Dialogue: How long were you up there ?

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: A long time.

Speaker: captain
Dialogue: A year ? Waiter another beer.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: I go up on missions. Listen Captain, buy me all the beer you want, but you better tell that asshole over there you're not going to find out anymore about me.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: What do you want ?

Speaker: civilian
Dialogue: If you're B.L. Willard, 4th Recon Group, we'd like you to come with us.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: Whose orders ?

Speaker: captain
Dialogue: Headquarters 11 Corps -- 405th A.S.A Battalion -- S-2 -- Com-Sec -- Intelligence -- Nha Trang.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: Who are you ?

Speaker: civilian
Dialogue: The agency.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: Captain B.L. Willard, G-4 Headquarters, reporting as ordered, sir.

Speaker: colonel
Dialogue: Have you ever seen this officer before, Captain Willard ?

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: No, sir.

Speaker: colonel
Dialogue: This gentleman or myself ?

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: No, sir.

Speaker: colonel
Dialogue: I believe on your last job you executed a tax collector in Kontum, is that right ?

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: I am not presently disposed to discuss that, sir.

Speaker: major
Dialogue: Very good.

Speaker: colonel
Dialogue: You know much about about Special Forces; Green Berets, Captain ?

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: I've worked with them on occasions and I saw the movie , sir.

Speaker: colonel
Dialogue: Then you can appreciate Command's concern over their -- shall we say 'erratic' methods of operation.  I have never favored elite units, Captain, including your paratroopers or whatever. Just because a man jumps out of an airplane or wears a silly hat doesn't give him any priviliges in my book -- not in this man's army.

Speaker: major
Dialogue: We didn't need 'em in Korea -- no sir, give me an Ohio farm boy and an M-1 Garand, none of this fancy crap -- no sir.

Speaker: civilian
Dialogue: Major.

Speaker: colonel
Dialogue: We have Special Forces A detachments all along the Cambodian border. Two here and another one here -- twelve or fourteen Americans -- pretty much on their own; they train and motivate Montagnard natives; pick their own operations. If they need something, they call for it, and get it within reason. What we're concerned with is here.

Speaker: colonel
Dialogue: The A detachment at Nu Mung Ba. It was originally a larger base, built up along the river in an old Cambodian fortress.

Speaker: colonel
Dialogue: ... Captain, we know something's going on up there -- Major --

Speaker: major
Dialogue: Communications naturally dwindled with the lack of V.C. activity, this is routine, expected ... but six months ago communication virtually stopped.

Speaker: colonel
Dialogue: About the same time -- large numbers of Montagnards of the M'Nong descent began leaving the area -- this in itself is not unusual since these people have fought with the Rhade Tribe that lived in the area for centuries. But what is unusual is that we began to find Rhade refugees too -- in the same sampans as the M'Nongs. These people aren't afraid of V.C. They've put up with war for twenty years -- but something is driving them out.

Speaker: major
Dialogue: We communicate with the base infrequently. What they call for are air strikes, immediate -- always at night. And we don't know what or who the air strikes are called on.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: Who ?

Speaker: major
Dialogue: You see, no one has really gone into this area and come back alive.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: Why me ?

Speaker: major
Dialogue: Walter Kurtz, Lieutenant Colonel, Special Forces. We understand you knew him.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: Yeah.

Speaker: colonel
Dialogue: He's commanding the detachment at Nu Mung Ba.

Speaker: second voice
Dialogue: Blue Delta five This Big Rhine -- three Need that ordinance immediately Goddamn give it to me immediate Christ -- Big Rhino -- Blue God -- Delta damn -- goddamn.

Speaker: third voice
Dialogue: This is Big Rhino six -- Blue Delta.

Speaker: major
Dialogue: That's Colonel Kurtz.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: I only met Kurtz once.

Speaker: civilian
Dialogue: Would he remember you ?

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: Maybe.

Speaker: colonel
Dialogue: What was your impression of him ?

Speaker: civilian
Dialogue: You didn't like him.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: Anyone got a cigarette.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: I thought he was a lame.

Speaker: colonel
Dialogue: A lame ?

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: This is years ago, before he joined Special Forces, I guess. We had an argument.

Speaker: colonel
Dialogue: About what ?

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: I don't know. He was a lame, that's all.

Speaker: colonel
Dialogue: But why ?

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: He couldn't get through a sentence without all these big words; about why we kill.

Speaker: colonel
Dialogue: Well, he's killing now.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: Maybe.

Speaker: civilian
Dialogue: What does that mean ?

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: Maybe it's not Kurtz. I don't believe he's capable of that. I just don't believe it.

Speaker: colonel
Dialogue: It's got to be Kurtz.

Speaker: civilian
Dialogue: The point is that Kurtz or somebody attacked a South Vietnamese Ranger Platoon three days ago. Last week a Recon helicopter was lost in the area -- another took heavy damage -- direct fire from their base camp.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: Our Recon flight ?

Speaker: civilian
Dialogue: Ours.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: Touchy.

Speaker: civilian
Dialogue: You can see, of course, the implications, if any of this -- even rumours leaked out.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: You want me to clean it up -- simple and quiet.

Speaker: civilian
Dialogue: Exactly -- you'll go up the Nung River in a Navy P.B.R. -- appear at Nu Mung Ba as if by accident, re-establish your acquintance with Colonel Kurtz, find out what's happened -- and why. Then terminate his command.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: Terminate ?

Speaker: civilian
Dialogue: Terminate with extreme prejudice.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: Chief, try to keep out of where we're going -- Why we're goin' and what's gonna be the big surprise.

Speaker: chief
Dialogue: All right with me, I used to drive a taxi.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: Let's go.

Speaker: chief
Dialogue: The Delta closes off to us about ten  miles out of Hau Fat. We'll be able to pick up some supplies -- bit I think there are only two points we can draw enough water to get into the Nung River. It's all Charlie's turf from there on out.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: We're gonna have some help to get in the river. You know these waters, Chief ?

Speaker: chief
Dialogue: 'Bout six months ago I took a man up to Lo Mung Bridge. He was regular Army too. Shot himself in the head. I brought his body back down.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: Shot himself. What for ?

Speaker: chief
Dialogue: Beats me -- the sun was too much for him, or the mud. Who knows ?

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: Arch light.

Speaker: chef
Dialogue: I hate that -- Every time I hear that noise something terrible happens.

Speaker: chief
Dialogue: Anybody see some smoke ?

Speaker: clean
Dialogue: Too far inland.

Speaker: lance
Dialogue: There they are.

Speaker: clean
Dialogue: Charlie don't ever hear 'em. Not till it's too late -- don't have to hit you neither, concussion'll do it for a quarter mile or better. Burst your ears -- suck the air outta your lungs.

Speaker: lance
Dialogue: Hey.

Speaker: chief
Dialogue: Lance -- I want you to go with the Captain an' get three extra drums of fuel and maybe scrounge some more 50 caliber.

Speaker: lance
Dialogue: Yeah -- look at those uniforms.

Speaker: chief
Dialogue: Poor bastards, have a long year to go.

Speaker: sergeant
Dialogue: I don't know anything about these papers, sir.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: They're in order -- it's perfectly clean -- just check with ComSec- Intel like I said.

Speaker: sergeant
Dialogue: Well, you know I don't have the priority to do that, sir. It says here not to contact Com-Sec- Int. Who's your commanding officer ?

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: Right now -- I am.

Speaker: sergeant
Dialogue: Well who the hell verifies that ?

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: I do.

Speaker: chief
Dialogue: No shit -- what's all the activity for around here ?

Speaker: sergeant
Dialogue: The show --

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: What show ?

Speaker: sergeant
Dialogue: Big show in the parade grounds this noon -- some boss stuff --

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: This -- Bob Hope or the like --

Speaker: sergeant
Dialogue: No sir, I think -- this'll be a little bit different --

Speaker: chief
Dialogue: Where's it gonna be ?

Speaker: chef
Dialogue: It's really too much -- I mean I've collected every picture of her since she was Miss December.

Speaker: clean
Dialogue: Yeah -- you can really get hung up on them like the cat in the Delta.

Speaker: chief
Dialogue: What cat  ?

Speaker: clean
Dialogue: One that went up for murder -- he was an Army Sergeant.

Speaker: chief
Dialogue: I never heard about that.

Speaker: clean
Dialogue: Yeah -- he really dug his Playboy mag, man -- I mean like he was there when it arrived -- He just knew.

Speaker: chef
Dialogue: So what happened ?

Speaker: clean
Dialogue: He was working A.R.V.N. patrols and had one a them little cocky gook asshole Lieutenants -- anyhow, the Lieutenant took his new Playboy one day, sat on the end of the dock, and wouldn't give it back.

Speaker: chef
Dialogue: Yeah -- typical A.R.V.N.

Speaker: clean
Dialogue: Then went too far -- he sat there and starts mutilating the centerfold. Poking pins in her an' all that. Sergeant says, don't do her like that. You leave your shitty little hands off that girl. Gook Lieutenant says Fuck you in Vietnamese -- Sergeant says, don't do that again. You'll wish you hadn't. Then he stood up, flicked his iron to rock and roll and gave the little zero a long burst through the Playboy mag. Man, it blew him clean off the dock -- Hell, just the magazine was floatin' there all full of holes.

Speaker: chief
Dialogue: They nail him for it bad ?

Speaker: clean
Dialogue: He's in the L.B.J. -- didn't give him no medals or nothing --

Speaker: agent
Dialogue: I'd like to say hello from all of us up here, to all of you out there. All of you who've worked so hard during Operation Brute Force -- Paratroopers -- Infantry -- Airmen -- Medics -- Marines -- and Sailors. And I want you to know that we feel proud of you and know how hard your job is. To prove it -- we've brought some entertainment we think you're gonna like: The Playmate of the Year and her two runners up !

Speaker: chief
Dialogue: Smoke !

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: Where ?

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: Black smoke ... secondary burning.

Speaker: chief
Dialogue: Yeah -- fishing village -- helicopters over there. Hueys, lots of 'em.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: First Air Cavalry. They're the ones gonna get us into the River.

Speaker: kilgore
Dialogue: Lieutenant: Bomb that tree line back about a hundred yards -- give me some room to breathe.

Speaker: kilgore
Dialogue: Bring me some cards.

Speaker: guard
Dialogue: Sir ?

Speaker: kilgore
Dialogue: Body cards, you damn fool -- cards !

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: Captain B-L. Willard, sir -- 4th Recon Group -- I carry priority papers from Com-Sec Intelligence 11 Corp -- I believe you understand the nature of my mission.

Speaker: kilgore
Dialogue: Yeah -- Na Trang told me to expect you -- we'll see what we can do. Just stay out of my way till this is done, Captain.

Speaker: kilgore
Dialogue: Six a spades -- eight a hearts -- Isn't one worth a Jack in this whole place.

Speaker: kilgore
Dialogue: What ? Here. You sure?

Speaker: kilgore
Dialogue: What's your name, sailor ?

Speaker: lance
Dialogue: Gunner's Mate, Third Class -- L. Johnson, sir.

Speaker: kilgore
Dialogue: Lance Johnson? The surfer?

Speaker: lance
Dialogue: That's right, sir.

Speaker: kilgore
Dialogue: It's an honor to meet you Lance. I've admired your nose-riding for years -- I like your cutback, too. I think you have the best cutback there is.

Speaker: lance
Dialogue: Thank you, sir.

Speaker: kilgore
Dialogue: You can cut out the sir, Lance -- I'm Bill kilgore -- I'm a goofy foot.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: My orders are from Com-Sec Intel -- B.L. Willard, 4th Recon --

Speaker: kilgore
Dialogue: Just hold up a second, Captain -- I'll get to you soon enough -- We've got things to do here.

Speaker: kilgore
Dialogue: ... we do a lot of surfing around here. Like to finish up operations early and fly down to Vung Tau for the evening glass. Have you ever surfed the point at Vung Tau? I liked the beach breaks around Na Trang a lot -- good lefts.

Speaker: kilgore
Dialogue: ... we keep three boards in my Command Huey at all times. You never can tell when you're gonna run into something good. I got a guy in Cam Rau Bay that can predict a swell two days in advance. We try to work it in.

Speaker: kilgore
Dialogue: Hell, that's an Ace if I ever saw one.

Speaker: kilgore
Dialogue: Where've you been riding, Lance?

Speaker: lance
Dialogue: I haven't surfed since I got here.

Speaker: kilgore
Dialogue: That's terrible -- we'll change that -- I'd like to see you work -- I've always liked your cutback; got a hell of a left turn, too.

Speaker: kilgore
Dialogue: Why the hell you wanna go up to Nu Mung Ba for?

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: I got bored in Saigon.

Speaker: kilgore
Dialogue: What's the furthest you been in?

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: Haiphong.

Speaker: kilgore
Dialogue: Haiphong? Shit, you jump in ?

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: No. Walked.

Speaker: kilgore
Dialogue: What'd you do for supplies?

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: Mercenaries -- agents, traitors -- they put out caches.

Speaker: kilgore
Dialogue: Can you trust them?

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: No. They put out two or three for every one I needed. When you get to the one you'll use, you just stake it out. If something feels wrong, you just pass it up. On one mission, I had to pass up three and ended up living on rats and chocolate bars.

Speaker: kilgore
Dialogue: Nu Mung Ba. Last I heard, Walter Kurtz commanded a Green Beret detachment at Nu Mung Ba.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: When did you hear?

Speaker: kilgore
Dialogue: 'Bout a year ago? Is Kurtz still alive?

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: Who knows.

Speaker: kilgore
Dialogue: Seems to me he got himself fragged. i heard some grunt rolled a grenade in his tent. Maybe a rumor. Helluva man -- remarkable officer. Walter Kurtz woulda been a General some day. General of the Army. Shit, Head of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. Did you knew Kurtz?

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: I met him.

Speaker: kilgore
Dialogue: Don't you agree?

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: He musta changed !  I got to get into the Nung River, here or here.

Speaker: kilgore
Dialogue: That village you're pointing at is kinda hairy.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: Hairy ?

Speaker: kilgore
Dialogue: I mean it's hairy -- they got some pretty heavy ordnance, boy -- I've lost a few recon ships in there now and again.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: So? I heard you had a good bunch of killers here.

Speaker: kilgore
Dialogue: And I don't intend to get some of them chewed up just to get your tub put in the mouth of the goddman Nung River. You say you don't know Kurtz?

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: I met him.

Speaker: kilgore
Dialogue: You talk like him. I don't mind taking casualties, Captain, but I like to keep my ratio ten to one in this unit -- ten Cong to one.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: You'll find enough Cong up there.

Speaker: kilgore
Dialogue: What about this point here?

Speaker: kilgore
Dialogue: What's the name of that goddamn village -- Vin Drin Dop or Lop; damn gook names all sound the same.

Speaker: kilgore
Dialogue: Mike, you know anything about the point at Vin Drip Drop?

Speaker: mike
Dialogue: Boss left.

Speaker: kilgore
Dialogue: What do you mean?

Speaker: mike
Dialogue: It's really long left slide, breaks on the short side of the point -- catches a south swell.

Speaker: lance
Dialogue: Nice.

Speaker: kilgore
Dialogue: Why the hell didn't you tell me about that place -- a good left.  There aren't any good left slides in this whole, shitty country. It's all goddamn beach break.

Speaker: mike
Dialogue: It's hairy ,though. That's where we lost McDonnel -- they shot the hell out of us. It's Charlie's point.

Speaker: kilgore
Dialogue: How big it is?

Speaker: mike
Dialogue: Six to eight feet.

Speaker: kilgore
Dialogue: A six-foot left.

Speaker: lance
Dialogue: Boss. What's the wind like.

Speaker: mike
Dialogue: Light off shore -- really hollow.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: We could go in tomorrow at dawn -- there's always off-shore wind in the morning.

Speaker: chief
Dialogue: The draft of that river might be too shallow on the point.

Speaker: kilgore
Dialogue: Hell, we'll pick your boat up and lay it down like a baby, right where you want it. This is the Cav boy -- airmobile. I can take that point and hold it as long as I like -- and you can get anywhere you want up that river that suits you, Captain. Hell, a six foot left.  You take a gunship back to division -- Mike, take Lance with you -- let him pick out a board, and bring me my Yater Spoon -- the eight six.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: I don't know, sir -- it's -- it's --

Speaker: kilgore
Dialogue: What is it?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Well, I mean it's hairy in there -- it's Charlie's point.

Dialogue: Charlie don't surf.

Speaker: kilgore
Dialogue: How do you feel, boy?

Speaker: gunner
Dialogue: Like a mean motherfucker, sir.

Dialogue: Let's go.

Dialogue: We'll come in low out of the rising sun -- We'll put on the music about a mile out.

Dialogue: Music?

Speaker: kilgore
Dialogue: Yeah. Classical stuff -- scares the hell out of the slopes -- the boys love it.

Dialogue: 700 -- 600 yards -- 500 -- Commence firing.

Dialogue: Big Duke Six to Hell's Angels Four -- bring it in on along tree line and huts.

Dialogue: Haven't got time, Hell's Angels -- lay it right up the tree line.

Speaker: kilgore
Dialogue: Fucking savages.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: Who?

Speaker: kilgore
Dialogue: The enemy. Who else?

Speaker: kilgore
Dialogue: Big Duke Six to Baker Delta Four -- hold -- we're right over you.

Speaker: kilgore
Dialogue: Right along the doors, boy.

Speaker: kilgore
Dialogue: Fine... fine... little higher. Through the roof; yeah, that's good.

Dialogue: Didn't anybody bring me any bombs, grenades, claymores or anything?

Dialogue: You didn't tell me to, sir.

Speaker: kilgore
Dialogue: You shoulda known.

Dialogue: Sonuvabitch -- anybody hurt?

Dialogue: Automatic weapons flashes along those trees -- probably eleven millimeter guns and AK-47's.

Dialogue: The trees, eh...

Dialogue: Eagle Thrust Four -- Big Duke Six. Join me in sparaying some trees.

Dialogue: Take her in low, Lieutenant.

Speaker: kilgore
Dialogue: Hold it, boy.

Dialogue: Take her up to 300 feet, Lieutenant.

Speaker: kilgore
Dialogue: Rifle.

Speaker: kilgore
Dialogue: My rifle, soldier.

Dialogue: Anyone got a card?

Dialogue: The L.Z.'s cooling off fast -- we'll move in another company an' then we'll own it.  Charlie's point.

Dialogue: Good swell.

Dialogue: What, sir?

Dialogue: I said it's a good swell -- hell of a good swell 'bout six feet. Let's get a look at it.

Dialogue: Incoming !

Dialogue: Look at that.

Dialogue: This  L.Z. is still pretty hot, sir, maybe we oughta stand somewhere else.

Dialogue: I'm waiting for the fucking boat, Colonel.

Dialogue: It'll get here, soldier.

Dialogue: Change.

Dialogue: Wh -- what?

Dialogue: Change -- get out there -- I want'a see if it's ridable -- change.

Dialogue: It's still pretty hairy, sir.

Dialogue: You want'a surf, soldier?

Dialogue: That's good, boy, because it's either surf or fight.

Dialogue: I'm gonna cover for 'em -- that's all.

Dialogue: You think that section on the point is ridable, Lance?

Dialogue: I think we ought to wait for the tide to come in.

Dialogue: Sure -- fine --

Dialogue: Maybe he'll get tubed.

Dialogue: Maybe he'll get inside the tube -- where -- where they can't see him.

Dialogue: Son of a bitch.

Dialogue: Just something I read in the Free Press.

Dialogue: They just missed a good set -- the chicken shits !

Dialogue: Im not afraid to surf this place. I'll surf this place.

Dialogue: Bring that R.T., soldier.

Dialogue: Big Duke Six to Hell's Angels -- Goddamit, I want that treeline bombed -- yeah -- napalm -- gimme some napalm -- son of a bitch -- yeah, I'll take H.Z. or C.B.U.'s if you got any of them -- just bomb 'em into the Stone Age, boy.

Dialogue: Son of a bitch.

Dialogue: He'll kill us.

Dialogue: You smell that?

Dialogue: What?

Dialogue: I love the smell of napalm in the morning.

Dialogue: What?

Dialogue: We have never heard of him.

Dialogue: Bon nuit, Roxanne -- bon nuit, Captain.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: Good night.

Dialogue: You must realize, Captain -- we have lost much here -- I, my husband. Gaston -- his wife and son.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: I'm sorry to hear that.

Speaker: roxanne
Dialogue: Cognac?

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: I should be checking on the boat.

Speaker: roxanne
Dialogue: The war will still be here tomorrow.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: I guess so.

Speaker: roxanne
Dialogue: Do you miss your home, Captain? Have you someone there?

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: No. Not really.

Speaker: roxanne
Dialogue: Then you are like us.

Speaker: roxanne
Dialogue: What will you do after the war?

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: I just follow my footsteps, one at a time, trying to answer the little questions and staying away from the big ones.

Speaker: roxanne
Dialogue: What's a big question?

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: Kurtz.  I know you've heard of him.

Speaker: roxanne
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: What did you hear?

Speaker: roxanne
Dialogue: That strange things.. terrible things have occured around this American, Kurtz.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: What things?

Speaker: roxanne
Dialogue: Gaston would never tell me. It was asubject not to be spoken of, Captain.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: roxanne
Dialogue: Did you know -- deeper in the jungle, upriver -- there are savages?

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: I know.

Speaker: roxanne
Dialogue: But Captain, I mean -- cannibals.

Speaker: roxanne
Dialogue: What a pity, you don't drink. Since my husband died, there are so many things I must do alone.

Speaker: roxanne
Dialogue: Are you warm, Captain?

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: The river is beautiful.

Speaker: roxanne
Dialogue: I spend hours watching that river from my bedroom window. It fascinates me.

Speaker: roxanne
Dialogue: I have been lonely here, Captain.

Speaker: roxanne
Dialogue: I will fix you breakfast.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: I'm afraid I won't have time -- I gotta --

Speaker: roxanne
Dialogue: Whe you reach the boat you will find that half your fifty calibre stores -- a case of grenades, a mortar and two M-16's and a case of clips are being transfered to us by your order.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: So that's it.

Speaker: roxanne
Dialogue: You may think what you wish, Captain, but I like you very much.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: What if I say no.

Speaker: roxanne
Dialogue: Then Philippe will have to kill all of you.

Speaker: gaston
Dialogue: Two of my men deserted last night. It happens from time to time. I assume my daughter told you of our conditions.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: Your daughter.

Speaker: chief
Dialogue: They taking half our ammo, Captain -- said it was your orders.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: That's right -- I did.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: I guess this is whAt men of war do -- eh?

Speaker: gaston
Dialogue: We endure, captain -- you can blow up the house and we will live in the cellar -- destroy that and we'll dig a hole in the jungle and sleep on it. Burn the forest and we'll hide in the swamp. all the while, we do but one thing -- clean the blood off our bayonets.  Au revoir, Captain.

Speaker: chief
Dialogue: Next time we  get in a good fire fight -- I'd like to know how she was, Captain.

Speaker: chef
Dialogue: Holy shit.

Speaker: clean
Dialogue: What did you put in all those ammo boxes?

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: Rocks, sand -- those two men who deserted.

Speaker: chief
Dialogue: When'd you do it?

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: While you were sleeping.

Speaker: chief
Dialogue: -- All right, Lance --

Speaker: lance
Dialogue: The other one --

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: No -- leave it --

Speaker: chief
Dialogue: Why -- Charlie put it there to kill --

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: Thta's not Charlie's work --

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: Whoever put'em there didn't do it to kill people -- They put 'em up as signs --

Speaker: chief
Dialogue: Signs?

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: Yeah -- like keep out --

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: Listen.

Speaker: chief
Dialogue: What is it?

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: Listen.

Speaker: chief
Dialogue: They're on the banks of the river.

Speaker: lance
Dialogue: Jesus !

Speaker: chief
Dialogue: No, Lance. Not while you can't see.

Speaker: chief
Dialogue: Will they attack?

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: If they have boats ... or canoes... they'd get lost in the fog. We can't move either -- we'll end up on the shore.

Speaker: chef
Dialogue: God...

Speaker: lance
Dialogue: Sounds like hundreds of them.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: Shhhhhh.

Dialogue: It doesn't sound hostile -- it sounds like they've seen us coming and it sounds like -- I don't know, a funeral. I don't understand.

Speaker: chief
Dialogue: Which way? Right or left?

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: Who knows? Right.

Speaker: chief
Dialogue: Looks pretty shallow.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: Purgative air strike ! Purgative ! They'd kill me too !

Speaker: chief
Dialogue: Shit ! Fucking arrows ! They're shooting fucking arrows at us.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: Steer her right.

Dialogue: A spear?

Dialogue: Stop it. Stop it !

Speaker: lance
Dialogue: Chief's dead.

Dialogue: Just stand here with me where they can see us. Do nothing.

Dialogue: We've been attacked.

Dialogue: I know, I know, it's all right. Come in this way. It's mined over there. This way. It's all right.

Dialogue: Charlie?

Dialogue: Looks that way.

Dialogue: Who's he?

Dialogue: God knows.

Dialogue: Who the hell are you?

Dialogue: Moonby what?

Dialogue: Moonby, 4th battalion, Royal Australian Regiment, Task Force. Ex-Corporal Moonby, deserted.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: What is this?

Speaker: moonby
Dialogue: Oh, they're simple enough people. It's good to see you, baby. Nobody has any Winstons?

Speaker: moonby
Dialogue: This boat's a mess.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: Where's Kurtz? I want to talk to him.

Speaker: moonby
Dialogue: Oh, you don't talk to Colonel Kurtz.  You listen to him. God, these are good. I kept these people off you, you know. It wasn't easy.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: Why did they attack us?

Speaker: moonby
Dialogue: Simple. They don't want him to go.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: You're Australian?

Speaker: moonby
Dialogue: Pre-Australian, actually. But I'd dig goin' to California. I'm California dreamin'.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: So Kurtz is alive.

Speaker: moonby
Dialogue: Kurtz. I tell you, that man has enlarged my mind.

Speaker: moonby
Dialogue: But lemme tell you, he is the most dangerous thing in every way that I've come on so far. He wanted to shoot me. Speaker: willard
Dialogue: Why didn't he shoot you?

Speaker: moonby
Dialogue: I've asked myself that question. I said to myself, why didn't he shoot me? He didn't shoot me, because I had a stash like you wouldn't believe. Speaker: chef
Dialogue: Love?

Speaker: moonby
Dialogue: Oh, no, not what you think... Cosmic love. He made me see things -- things, you know.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: Sounds like he's gone crazy.

Speaker: moonby
Dialogue: No, Colonel Kurtz couldn't be crazy -- if you heard him talk, just last week, you'd never think he was crazy.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: Is that where he is? By the shrunken heads.

Speaker: moonby
Dialogue: Those heads, yes. Well, the rebels...

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: We're going ashore. Tie her up -- and leave your guns up, Lance.

Speaker: lance
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: Bring your rifles, that's all.  Take us to him.

Speaker: moonby
Dialogue: Right on -- he's been waiting for --

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: And shut up.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: Who are you?

Speaker: moonby
Dialogue: His name is...

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: I'm not ever goin' to tell you to shut up again.

Dialogue: What happened here?

Speaker: colby
Dialogue: What -- happened here.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: Charlie?

Dialogue: NVA regulars. They're coming again tonight. Tet -- their big -- assault.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: I'm taking you back.

Speaker: moonby
Dialogue: Oh, no, dont say that.

Speaker: colby
Dialogue: Take us back. Take us back ! But, the operation -- the team. Colonel Kurtz has such plans for -- the team.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: Take me to him, Major.

Speaker: colby
Dialogue: I had nothing to do with these operations -- I did not do the planning -- none of us did. It was all Colonel Kurtz -- he was the genius. You'll see -- the genius of our Colonel. He should be made a General, don't you think? A General? It's...

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: Colonel Kurtz, I guess.

Speaker: kurtz
Dialogue: I'm Kurtz.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: Captain B.L. Willard reporting his presence, sir.

Speaker: kurtz
Dialogue: At ease...  Sit down.

Speaker: kurtz
Dialogue: Why did you come to ... my province.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: We were attacked -- down river. We need supplies and medical help.

Speaker: kurtz
Dialogue: You were not coming here, to see me?

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: No -- no, sir.

Speaker: kurtz
Dialogue: You came up my river -- in that small boat. So simple. I always thought the final justice would come from the sky, like we did.  You are the final justice, aren't you?

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: What do you mean, Colonel?

Speaker: kurtz
Dialogue: What other reason could you have come? A Captain. Ranger. Paratrooper. Graduate of the Recondo School. Am I right about these things?

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: You know you're right.

Speaker: kurtz
Dialogue: Then the Agency approached you. Maybe in a bar in Quinon or Pleiku. Simple. A year's pay for one life. Perhaps a village elder, or a tax collector. Nobody's orders but your own. Exciting work.

Speaker: kurtz
Dialogue: You've spent tome at the Royal Tracking School of Malaysia. I can tell from the way the laces on your boots are tied. I understand you, Captain. We understand each other.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: Do you know me?

Speaker: kurtz
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: kurtz
Dialogue: Do you know me ?

Speaker: chef
Dialogue: Holy shit.

Speaker: chef
Dialogue: Captain -- they've been probed all this week -- Cong and NVA regulars. There's gonna be a big offense any time.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: I know.

Speaker: chef
Dialogue: What are we doing here?

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: Kurtz. I'm supposed to kill him, just like he said.

Speaker: kurtz
Dialogue: Yeah, I can see that. He's fuckin nuts --

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: Yeah.

Speaker: chef
Dialogue: He killed that guy without feeling anything.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: Not a thing.

Speaker: chef
Dialogue: When you kill Cong, don't you feel something.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: Sure.  Recoil... I feel the recoil of my rifle.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: This is good -- triple overlapping fields of fire -- walls so thick ordinary artillery just cleans the moss off their surfaces.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: I've done things, when I was alone in the jungle -- that I never told anyone about.

Speaker: chef
Dialogue: This is evil -- evil, Captain. We're all gonna die here.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: Yeah, I know.

Speaker: chef
Dialogue: I don't get it -- You said your mission was to kill him. Let's do it, an' get our asses outta here. This  Kurtz is ruining the war; I mean, this don't look good for America !

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: ... he's an amazing officer.

Speaker: chef
Dialogue: You got to kill this sonuvabitch -- Lance and me, we don't understand none of this -- Jesus, Captain -- I don't wanna die here -- Do it quick.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: Yeah. I know.

Speaker: moonby
Dialogue: He's asleep -- don't bother him.

Speaker: kurtz
Dialogue: I'm awake.

Speaker: kurtz
Dialogue: You. Get out.

Speaker: kurtz
Dialogue: Hes only stayed alive this long because he's a good orderly and medic. He knows how to use a hypodermic.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: You're gonna get hit tonight, bad -- a whole regiment of NVA regulars.

Speaker: kurtz
Dialogue: That's right, the little gook- pricks. But they are noble little gook-pricks, noble. Because they fight with their guts, like animals. And for an idea ! That's rich. We fight with ingenious machines and fire, like Gods, and for nothing. But I'll call in a major blotto airstrike tonight. We'll have ourselves a helluva airstrike tonight, a lightshow. How do you like The Doors': 'C'mon Baby Light My Fire...'

Speaker: kurtz
Dialogue: Do you?

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: Yeah, I like it...

Speaker: kurtz
Dialogue: I love it.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: You've gone crazy.

Speaker: kurtz
Dialogue: But my soul has gone mad.

Speaker: kurtz
Dialogue: My gut -- Oh, Christ, my gut !

Speaker: chef
Dialogue: Kill him -- come on, why don't you kill him

Speaker: kurtz
Dialogue: Oh shit -- on the table; morphine.

Speaker: kurtz
Dialogue: You see how stupid it would have been to blow out my brains? I'm dying from the gut anyway.

Speaker: kurtz
Dialogue: No -- I don't want to sleep. I want to think. Water. Give me water.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: You can't have water after morphine.

Speaker: kurtz
Dialogue: Still playing by the rules.  You're a damn good kiler.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: How's the pain?

Speaker: kurtz
Dialogue: How's yours?

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: I can handle it.

Speaker: kurtz
Dialogue: Pain is easy to handle -- but nobility.. the nobility of a man is judged by how much Truth he can handle.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: What Truth?

Speaker: kurtz
Dialogue: The truth that you were sent here to murder me, ans so far you haven't done it. And do you know why?  Except me.

Speaker: kurtz
Dialogue: Gimme water.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: No water.

Speaker: kurtz
Dialogue: You know what you're doing? You are interfering with my plans !

Speaker: kurtz
Dialogue: This water's got Moonby's acid in it --

Speaker: kurtz
Dialogue: Drink it -- drink it for tonight. Think of it. A whole regiment of those shitty little Cong -- War. Total war -- war like you've never known it. It's beautiful -- you'll love it. Trust me.

Speaker: chef
Dialogue: Lance -- the fucker's not gonna do it.

Speaker: kurtz
Dialogue: Goddamn -- You've gotta dig napalm on Speed, too. It's spectacular, you'll see.

Speaker: kurtz
Dialogue: Look into the jungle. You can't -- it's too terrible. You have to smear yourself with warpaint to look at it -- you have to be a cannibal.  That's why warpaint was invented. Then it becomes your jungle.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: How did we get here?

Speaker: kurtz
Dialogue: Because of all the things we do, the thing we do best -- is lie.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: I think think a lie stinks.

Speaker: kurtz
Dialogue: Oh Captain, that is so true.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: Stinks. I could never figure --  I could never figure how they can teach boys how to bomb villages with napalm -- and not let them write the word 'fuck' on their airplanes.

Speaker: kurtz
Dialogue: You could never figure it because it doesn't make sense.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: Fuck no.

Speaker: kurtz
Dialogue: I'll tell you what makes sense ! Air strikes ! White Phosphorus ! Napalm ! We'll bomb the shit out of them if they don't do what we want.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: We'll exterminate the fuckers !

Speaker: chef
Dialogue: Captain -- kill him.

Speaker: kurtz
Dialogue: Think of it -- for years, millions of years, savages with pathetic painted faces were scared shitless that fire would rain down from the sky. And goddamn, we made it happen. God  bless  Dow  !

Speaker: chef
Dialogue: Kill him !

Speaker: lance
Dialogue: Hot damn !

Speaker: soldier
Dialogue: Wow...

Speaker: kurtz
Dialogue: Mini-gun. Colby. Sergeant. Mini-gun.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: Napalm.

Speaker: kurtz
Dialogue: Claymores, claymores.

Dialogue: Code -- Street Gang -- Street Gang ! Purgative air strike; Street Gang !

Speaker: kurtz
Dialogue: Charles !

Dialogue: Go away -- hide yourself.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: What are you doing?

Dialogue: Going back  - to the jungle to die.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: I'm taking you back. You can still live.

Dialogue: I had immense plans.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: I'm gonna get you out of here.

Speaker: kurtz
Dialogue: I was on threshold of great things.

Speaker: colby
Dialogue: Who is he?

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: He was the tragedy -- the tragedy of this war.

Speaker: kurtz
Dialogue: Don't. Don't frighten them away.

Dialogue: So you understand this?

Speaker: kurtz
Dialogue: Do I not?

Dialogue: My river... my people... my jungle... my ideas... my country... my wife...  ... my death.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: You had immense plans... immense plans...

Speaker: kurtz
Dialogue: Yes...

Dialogue: I'm taking you back.

Dialogue: The horror, the horror.

Dialogue: There.

Dialogue: How did they know?

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: They must have seen the fire.

Dialogue: They're coming to rescue us. They're Medevac.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: They're coming to take us back.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: Yeah.

Dialogue: Colonel Kurtz, he's dead.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: Yeah.

Dialogue: Yeah.

Dialogue: I never answered questions about Kurtz -- I gave them a few of his unimportant papers -- but for the most part I saved everything. There were other letters, personal ones written earlier to his wife. I brought them to het. I watched the fall of Saigon on television in a bar in Alameda...

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: Hi.

Speaker: kurtz's wife
Dialogue: Come in, Captain Willard.

Speaker: kurtz's wife
Dialogue: Can I get anything for you?

Speaker: kurtz's wife
Dialogue: Did you know him very well?

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: You get to know each other pretty well out there.

Speaker: kurtz's wife
Dialogue: And you admired him?

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: He was a remarkable man. It was impossible not to --

Speaker: kurtz's wife
Dialogue: Love him... Yes, it is true. That's the hard part for me... I knew him better than anyone ... I knew him best.

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: You knew him best.

Speaker: kurtz's wife
Dialogue: You were his friend... You must have been, if he had given you this...  If he sent you to his home. He was the best this country had -- he was --

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: Yes, I know...

Speaker: kurtz's wife
Dialogue: I'll never get over it -- But I'll always remember him...

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: Both of us...

Dialogue: Men looked up to him...  He died as he lived...

Speaker: willard
Dialogue: His death was -- yes, he died as he lived.

Dialogue: Were you with him, when...

Dialogue: Yes I was... He said his last words to me.

Dialogue: What were they?

Dialogue: Tell me.

Dialogue: Tell me what he said.
